items.title: TUD Graduation
items.description: I graduated with a BSc (Honours) in Information Technology from Technological University Dublin, specializing in Software Development, with additional training in Cloud Computing and AI/Machine Learning.

episodes.episode_name: Year 1: Foundations in Computing and Critical Skills
episodes.episode_description: The first year focused on building foundational skills across computing disciplines. I learned the basics of software development, computer architecture, and critical skills development. Courses like Software Development 1 and Discrete Mathematics 1 laid the groundwork for problem-solving and programming logic. The inclusion of Visual Design & User Experience and Social Media Communications provided insights into user-centered design and digital communication, while courses like Database Fundamentals and Systems Analysis set the stage for understanding how software systems are planned and structured.

episodes.episode_name: Year 2: Expanding Knowledge in Networking and Software Quality
episodes.episode_description: The second year introduced more advanced topics in software engineering and network infrastructure. Courses like Software Development 3, Network Fundamentals, and Software Quality Assurance & Testing deepened my knowledge in writing efficient, secure, and maintainable code. The curriculum also introduced web technologies with Client-Side Web Development, while courses such as Advanced Database Technologies enhanced my skills in managing and analyzing data. This year was key in transitioning from theory to practical application, with a focus on networking, information security, and project management.

episodes.episode_name: Year 3: Specialization in Cloud Services, Data Analysis, and Internship
episodes.episode_description: Year three marked a deeper dive into specialized topics, particularly in cloud computing, data analysis, and distributed systems. In addition to learning about scalable systems and data-driven solutions, I took an elective in Data Analysis, which introduced me to essential concepts in data preparation, statistical description, and model evaluation. The module covered topics like data summarization, hypothesis testing, and relationships between data attributes. The semester also included a hands-on experiential learning module, where I completed a six-month internship with the Department of Social Protection. This placement allowed me to apply classroom knowledge to real-world challenges, gaining professional experience in software development and cloud infrastructure.

episodes.episode_name: Year 4: Advanced Topics in AI, Cloud, and Industry Applications
episodes.episode_description: The final year of the program involved advanced courses in AI, machine learning, and cloud architecture. I worked on an extensive project while studying courses like Enterprise Applications Development, Applied Machine Learning, and Security for the Cloud and IoT. Electives such as Applied Artificial Intelligence and Deep Learning allowed me to explore cutting-edge technologies. The capstone project and modules in computational theory and user experience design tied together everything I had learned, preparing me for both industry challenges and further specialization in technology-driven fields.

items.title: Tallaght Hospital Healthcare Hackathon
items.description: During the 2nd annual Health Hackathon, hosted by TU Dublin and Tallaght University Hospital, I was part of a diverse team that tackled real-world healthcare problems. Our project was a Warfarin Patient App designed for better home monitoring of patients. This 24-hour event was an intensive experience, blending collaboration, creativity, and learning. We received guidance from experts in healthcare, data security, and cloud computing, which helped us shape a patient-centered solution. Our concept was recognized for its practicality and potential for positive impact on patient care. This experience highlighted the importance of teamwork, quick thinking, and applying theoretical knowledge to practical challenges.

episodes.episode_description: The hackathon kicked off with over 40 students from TU Dublin gathering at the Synergy Centre on the Tallaght campus. The event started with an introduction to the five healthcare challenges set by clinicians from Tallaght University Hospital, followed by insightful sessions on topics like ethics, data privacy, cyber security, and GDPR. These were critical considerations for any healthcare solution we were about to develop. Afterward, we had one-on-one time with each clinician to dive deeper into the specific problems and gather detailed requirements. This session allowed our team to gain a clear understanding of the issues at hand, which was essential before we moved into ideation.

After the briefings, our team immediately got to work brainstorming potential solutions. We explored multiple concepts, considering their feasibility, technical requirements, and potential impact on patient care. Through discussion and collaboration, we decided to focus on developing a Warfarin Patient App to help patients monitor their medication at home. The app would provide a simple, patient-friendly interface for tracking dosage, reminders, and medical data, with the goal of improving patient outcomes and reducing hospital visits. We spent the night conducting research, creating wireframes, and leveraging fast prototyping methods using cloud services, as demonstrated earlier by TU Dublinâ€™s technical presentation. This phase was both intense and rewarding as we iterated through ideas and refined our approach, ready to present the next day.

With the concept solidified, the focus shifted to execution. We split tasks among the team, with some members working on building a prototype interface while others concentrated on preparing the presentation materials. We developed a working prototype that showcased the core features of the Warfarin Patient App, including real-time tracking, notifications, and an easy-to-use interface. Additionally, we created a detailed poster that visually explained our solution, from the problem statement and research insights to the proposed features and benefits. After hours of polishing both the prototype and the presentation, we presented our solution to a panel of judges, explaining how it directly addresses the needs of patients and healthcare providers. The judges were impressed with our clear, patient-centric approach and the potential impact of the solution.

The hackathon concluded with an award ceremony where our team was announced as the first-place winners. Our Warfarin Patient App was praised for being 'applicable, relevant, patient-centered, and something that could be implemented in real-world healthcare settings.' The experience of working through the night, overcoming challenges, and collaborating under pressure was immensely valuable. We gained practical insights into the healthcare industry, learned the importance of rapid prototyping, and developed solutions that could genuinely make a difference in patient care. The event not only highlighted the importance of teamwork and quick thinking but also fostered lasting relationships with clinicians, industry experts, and our fellow participants. The recognition was the perfect capstone to an intense but rewarding 24 hours, and we left the event inspired to continue exploring healthcare technology solutions in the future.

items.title: Nvidia Certificate in Fundamentals of Deep Learning
items.description: Completed the 'Fundamentals of Deep Learning' course by Nvidia, focusing on deep learning mechanisms, data augmentation, transfer learning, and real-world AI applications.

items.title: Blended IP Week at HCAIM
items.description: Participated in the HCAIM Erasmus+ Blended Intensive Programme, gaining practical experience in AI ethics, data bias analysis, and presenting AI solutions.

episodes.episode_description: The program began with introductory sessions led by industry professionals and academics, setting the stage for problem-solving exercises focused on AI ethics and bias.
Throughout the week, I collaborated with peers to develop research proposals and solutions, addressing challenges related to data bias and ethical AI implementations.
Our group presented a detailed poster summarizing our findings and proposed solutions, receiving valuable feedback from experts that helped refine our approach.
The program concluded with reflections on the importance of ethical considerations in AI. I left with enhanced knowledge and a stronger understanding of AIâ€™s societal impacts.

items.title: Mockflix Portfolio
items.description: Developed a portfolio project styled like a streaming platform to showcase completed works.

episodes.episode_description: The project started with the idea of creating a portfolio styled like a streaming platform, allowing for a unique presentation of my completed works.
Using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, I built the platform, focusing on a user-friendly interface that mimics the navigation and layout of popular streaming services.
I integrated my projects into the portfolio, adding interactive elements like search functionality and dynamic content filtering to enhance the user experience.
The portfolio was deployed and shared across professional networks. Future updates include additional projects and refined user experience based on feedback.

items.title: Minifig Collector
items.description: A project focused on managing and collecting digital mini-figures with a user-friendly interface.

episodes.episode_description: The project was born out of a passion for collecting and organizing digital mini-figures, leading to the creation of an intuitive management platform.
I designed the interface to be clean and accessible, prioritizing ease of use while incorporating features like filtering, sorting, and search options.
The project involved integrating a backend database to store and retrieve collectible data, ensuring a seamless user experience across the platform.
The platform was launched successfully, receiving positive feedback for its design and functionality. Future updates include expanding collectible categories and adding user-driven features.

items.title: Agile Mate
items.description: Developed Agile Mate, an app designed to notify users of critical issues in Jira and facilitate casual discussion for problem-solving.

episodes.episode_description: The project began with identifying a common challenge in software development: quickly addressing critical issues in Jira without disrupting team flow.
Using React Native, Jira SDK, and Firebase, I developed a mobile app that integrates seamlessly with Jira, providing real-time notifications and easy access to discussions.
The app was designed with a focus on user experience, ensuring that key information is easily accessible on mobile screens without overwhelming the user.
The app was deployed and tested in a live environment, with plans for future enhancements such as additional integrations and customizable notification settings.

items.title: Executive Officer (Feb 2022 - Jul 2022)
items.description: During my internship at the Department of Social Protection, I played a key role in enhancing the user experience and functionality of two major web platforms, MyWelfare and MyGovID.

episodes.episode_description: My role began with understanding the critical requirements for improving the MyWelfare and MyGovID platforms, focusing on user experience and system reliability.
I contributed to the development and testing of new features, ensuring seamless integration and functionality across both platforms, while also identifying and fixing bugs.
Working closely with the development team, I helped meet project milestones on time, gaining experience in professional collaboration and software development practices.
The internship concluded with the successful deployment of enhanced features, leading to a more user-friendly experience for citizens using the MyWelfare and MyGovID platforms.
